summary: the list of federal quarantinable diseases in the united states had not been revised since 1983. it included cholera, diphtheria, infectious tuberculosis, plague, smallpox, yellow fever, and viral hemorrhagic fevers such as marburg, ebola, and Congo-Crimean (4–6). in canada, the provincial government made SARS a reportable, virulent, communicable disease. CDC has deferred to state and local health authorities in primary use of their own separate “police power” quarantine authorities to restrict the movement of persons within their boundaries. a lesson learned from the outbreak is that federal, state, and local officials will have to work closely in coordinating quarantine actions at all levels of government. legal issues are nearly always intertwined with public health responses. communication between public health lawyers at all levels is a crucial part of the new normal in public health. a web-based clearinghouse is available at http://www.phppo.cdc.gov/od/phlp/
